title: In his biography on President Warren Harding, Francis Russell says that former Pres Theodore Roosevelt said he wanted then-Sen Harding as his running mate in the 1920 presidential election. Did TR really considered Harding as a running mate? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kind of. Here’s what happened: Teddy Roosevelt succeeded to the presidency in 1901 when President McKinley was assassinated. TR was only 42 at the time, and he was — and remains — the youngest president in U.S. history. Three years later, in 1904, Roosevelt unanimously received the GOP nomination for president, and he easily beat Alton Parker, the Democratic candidate, to win a term in his own right. Four years after that, Roosevelt declined to run for a second full term, and he essentially hand-picked his successor, William Howard Taft. Taft won the party nomination on the first ballot, and in the general election, he handed William Jennings Bryan his third presidential election loss. As Taft’s term wore on, Teddy Roosevelt became more and more disenchanted with Taft, to the point of openly criticizing him. In 1912, Roosevelt — who was still only 53 years old — sought the Republican nomination at their convention in June, but party stalwarts stuck with Taft. Roosevelt, not to be denied, decided to run as a Third Party candidate, under the Progressive or Bull Moose Party banner. While Roosevelt became the most successful third-party candidate in U.S. history, before or since, his entrance only succeed in splitting the Republican vote, and Wilson won the election by a large margin. In 1918, Roosevelt dedicated himself to helping the Republicans win back control of Congress in the off-year elections, and by late 1918, TD was widely viewed as the leading candidate for the presidency in 1920. It was at this point that Roosevelt wrote a letter to noted journalist William Allen White in which he suggested that Ohio Senator Warren G. Harding would make an effective running-mate. Time, and Roosevelt’s poor health, nullified those plans, and Roosevelt died in January 1919 at the age of 60.

That would not be surprising. There is a reason why Harding won the Republican nomination for President, despite his obvious deficiencies in that role. (In those days, winning the Republican nomination was almost tantamount to winning the Presidency). There were three strong candidates at the Republican convention, and none of the three would back down and support one of the others. So Harding was nominated for President as everyone’s “second” choice. Because, in fact, he was considered a good “back up” man. Harding was a tall, well spoken man who looked and acted like a President. The reason he was nobody’s first choice was because he was actually not considered smart enough to do the job. But the Republican party saw him as an “executive vice president” type of person whom a “real” candidate would like to show the public as “this is the man who will take my place if anything happens to me.” Harding was a great “sidekick” like the Lone Ranger’s “Tonto” (the name means “fool” in Spanish). When there were too many “lone rangers” and only one “Tonto,” then the purported sidekick got the nod. (The party put a much brighter man named Calvin Coolidge under him.) But if Teddy Roosevelt were the “lone ranger,” he would want the much younger Harding as his “Tonto.”
